title: Motivation
description:
Basic systems that get us going 
  (and keep us going).

theories.title: Acquired Needs Theory
theories.description:
we seek power,
    achievement or affiliation.

theories.title:
Activation 
Theory
theories.description: We have a need for arousal.

theories.title: Affect Perseverance
theories.description:
Preference persists 
  after disconfirmation.

theories.title: Attitude-Behavior Consistency
theories.description: factors that align attitude and behavior.

theories.title: Attribution Theory
theories.description:
we need to
    attribute cause, that supports our ego.

theories.title: Cognitive Dissonance
theories.description:
non-alignment is
    uncomfortable.

theories.title: Cognitive Evalution Theory
theories.description:
we
    select tasks based on how doable they are.

theories.title: Consistency Theory
theories.description:
we seek the comfort of
    internal alignment.

theories.title: Control Theory
theories.description:
we seek to control the world around
us.

theories.title: Disconfirmation bias
theories.description:
Agreeing with what 
  supports beliefs and vice versa.

theories.title:
Drive

theories.description: We seek to satisfy needs.

theories.title:
Endowed 
Progress Effect
theories.description: Progress is motivating.

theories.title: ERG Theory
theories.description:
We seek to fulfill needs of

theories.title: Escape Theory
theories.description: We seek to escape uncomfortable realities.

theories.title: Expectancy Theory

We are motivated by

theories.title: Extrinsic Motivation

external: tangible

different types of goals motivate us

theories.title: Intrinsic Motivation

internal:

our commitment

theories.title: Opponent-Process Theory
theories.description:
opposite emotions

theories.title: Optimism Bias
theories.description:
We assume we will be more 
successful than others.

theories.title:
Placebo 
Effect
theories.description: We believe and respond to fakes.

theories.title: Positive Psychology
theories.description: What makes us happy.

theories.title: Reactance Theory
theories.description:
discomfort when freedom is
    threatened.

theories.title:
Self-Determination 
Theory
theories.description: External and internal motivation.

theories.title: Self-Discrepancy Theory
theories.description:
we need

theories.title: Side Bet Theory
theories.description:
aligned side-bets increase

theories.title:
The 
Transtheoretical Model of Change
theories.description: Stages in changing oneself.

theories.title: Automatic Believing
theories.description:
we initially

theories.title: Belief Bias
theories.description:
We accept things that fit into

theories.title: Belief Perseverance
theories.description:
once formed, a
    belief will persist.

theories.title: Conversion
theories.description:
beliefs can change suddenly when
    we see the light.

theories.title: Disconfirmation bias
theories.description:
Agreeing with what 
  supports beliefs and vice versa.

theories.title: Fowler's Faith Stage Theory
theories.description: stages of different levels of religious belief.

theories.title: Just-world phenomenon
theories.description:
Good and bad will be 
  rewarded and punished.

theories.title:
Placebo 
Effect
theories.description: We believe and respond to fakes.

theories.title: Polarization
theories.description: Taking increasingly extreme views.

theories.title: Schema
theories.description:
we believe our internal models are

theories.title: Selective Perception
theories.description:
we see things

theories.title: Source Credibility
theories.description:
Who we are likely to

title: Meaning
description:
How we make sense of the world and

theories.title:
Amplification 
Hypothesis
theories.description: Certainty hardens attitude.

theories.title: Attribution Theory
theories.description:
We need to
    attribute cause, that supports our ego.

theories.title: Constructivism
theories.description:
We use constructs as
    perceptual categories.

theories.title: Focusing effect
theories.description:
We pay more attention to some 
  things than others.

theories.title: Framing
theories.description:
Mental combinations that affect

theories.title: Just-world phenomenon
theories.description:
Good and bad will be 
  rewarded and punished.

theories.title: Objectification
theories.description:
We simplify

theories.title: Personal Construct Theory
theories.description:
Constructs that

theories.title: Positive psychology
theories.description: What makes us happy.

theories.description: Mental structure to organize and interpret the world.

theories.description:
Preference persists

Thinking then

theories.description:
emotions

Emotion

theories.title: Durability bias
theories.description:
we over-estimate how long

theories.title: Fatigue
theories.description: The effects of tiredness.

theories.title: Focalism
theories.description:
we think an emotion is driven by a single

theories.title: Impact bias
theories.description:
over-estimating the effect of

theories.title: James-Lange Theory of Emotion
theories.description: physiological changes lead to emotions.

theories.title: Love
theories.description: different types of affection.

theories.title: Mood-Congruent Judgment
theories.description:
Our moods
    bias our judgments.

theories.title: Mood memory
theories.description:
We recall things that match our
current mood.

theories.title: Opponent-Process Theory
theories.description:
opposite emotions

theories.title: Social Contagion
theories.description:
we catch emotions
    from others.

theories.title: Two-Factor Theory of Emotion
theories.description:
we deduce
    feelings from our situation.

theories.title: Availability Heuristic
theories.description:
recent
    events seem more likely.

theories.title:
Choice-supportive 
bias
theories.description: Distorting memories to make decisions seem good.

theories.title: Counterfactual Thinking
theories.description:
We can change

theories.title: False Memory Syndrome
theories.description:
We can create memories

theories.title: False Recognition

Words can change what we

theories.title: Fatigue
theories.description: The effects of tiredness.

theories.title: Hindsight Bias
theories.description:
we pretend we remembered

theories.title: Mood memory
theories.description:
We recall things that match our

theories.description: we remember what happened first.

theories.title: Recency Effect
theories.description: we remember recent stuff.

theories.title: Von Restorff Effect
theories.description:
we remember

theories.description:
Remembering when we were

How we pay attention to things

we attach to others in

theories.description:
we seek confirmation that

theories.title: Information Processing Theory

theories.title: Ironic Reversal
theories.description:
we cannot avoid

theories.title: Selective Exposure
theories.description:
we avoid what

theories.description:
We sometimes think

theories.description:
when we do a

theories.title: Bias Blind Spot
theories.description:
We do not compensate enough

Choice-supportive 
bias
theories.description: Distorting memories to make decisions seem good.

we over-estimate how long

Theory
theories.description: Minorities can convert majority people.

theories.title: Door In The Face (DITF)
theories.description:
Cause rejection then make 
  real offer.

theories.title:
Foot In The 
Door (FITD)
theories.description: Make small offer then increase.

theories.title: Forced Compliance
theories.description: Obligation to obey.

theories.title:
Identifiable 
Victim Effect
theories.description: Empathizing with one more than many.

theories.title: Information Manipulation Theory
theories.description: Breaking one of the four conversational maxims.

theories.title: Persuasion
theories.description: factors important in persuasion.

theories.title: Priming
theories.description: Setting up memory to be used later.

theories.title: Reciprocity Norm
theories.description:
we feel obliged to
    return favors.

theories.title: Scarcity Principle
theories.description:
we want what is of
    limited availability.

theories.title: Sleeper Effect
theories.description:
when persuasive messages
    increase effectiveness over time.

theories.title: Social Influence
theories.description:
How we are strongly 
influenced by others.

theories.title: Subliminal Messages
theories.description:
famous method that is
    a sham.

theories.title: Ultimate Terms
theories.description:
some words are particularly
    powerful.

theories.title: Weak Ties Theory
theories.description: How far does influence go?

theories.title: Yale Attitude Change Approach
theories.description: factors important in persuasion.

theories.title: Compensation
theories.description:
acting to disconfirm negative
    perception from others.

theories.title: Inoculation
theories.description:
a weak argument increases
    ability to resist it.

theories.title: Insufficient Punishment
theories.description:
we 
  devalue a resisted desired object.

theories.title: Ben Franklin Effect
theories.description:
when we do a
    favor, we like them even more.

theories.title: Communication Accommodation Theory
theories.description: we morph to be like others.

theories.title: Contact Hypothesis
theories.description:
bringing enemies
    together helps make them friends.

theories.title: Credibility
theories.description:
factors which increase trust
    and credibility.

theories.title: Source Credibility
theories.description:
Who we are likely to 
  believe.

theories.title: Theory of Mind
theories.description: Guessing what they are thinking.

theories.title:
Kouzes and Posner's Leadership 
  Participation Inventory

title: Lies
description: Telling things that are not true.

theories.title: Four-factor Model
theories.description:
there are four 
  underlying things happening when people lie.

theories.title: Information Manipulation Theory
theories.description: Breaking one of the four conversational maxims to persuade.

theories.title: Interpersonal Deception Theory
theories.description: lying is a dynamic dance of liar and listener.

theories.title:
Placebo 
Effect
theories.description: We believe and respond to fakes.

title: Power
description: Being able to achieve our goals.

theories.title: Coercion
theories.description:
is acting to change a person's
    behavior against their will.

theories.title: Least Interest Principle
theories.description:
the person
    with the least interest has most power.

theories.title: Power
theories.description:
is the ability to get a person to change their
    behavior.

theories.title: Social Exchange Theory
theories.description:
give in order to get 
more.

theories.title: Strategic Contingencies Theory
theories.description:
power 
depends on problem skill, centrality and uniqueness of skill.

theories.title: Ben Franklin Effect
theories.description:
after helping
    another person we like them more.

theories.title: Contact Hypothesis
theories.description:
bringing enemies
    together leads towards friendship.

theories.title: Dilution Effect
theories.description:
information about others
reduces stereotyping.

theories.title: Empathy-Altruism Hypothesis
theories.description:
if we
    feel empathy we are likely to help.

theories.title: Friendship
theories.description:
there are several factors that increase
    chances of friendship.

theories.title: Law of Attraction
theories.description:
similar attitudes
    leads to friendship.

theories.title: Matching Hypothesis
theories.description:
romantic
    partners tend to be similarly attractive.

theories.title: Mere Exposure Theory
theories.description:
exposure to people
    increases liking.

theories.title: The Pratfall Effect
theories.description: Being clumsy makes you likeable.

theories.title: Propinquity Effect
theories.description:
meeting and
    interacting increase chance of friendship.

theories.title: Reinforcement-Affect Theory
theories.description:
both forms
    of conditioning leads us to like others.

theories.title: Repulsion Hypothesis
theories.description:
we prefer
    those with similar attitudes (and vice versa).

theories.title: Classical Conditioning
theories.description:
a
    repeated stimulus will trigger associated event.

theories.title: Control Theory
theories.description:
we seek to control the world around
us.

theories.title: Deindividuation
theories.description: losing our sense of self.

theories.title: Ego Depletion
theories.description: Controlling urges is exhausting.

theories.title: Extended Parallel Process Model
theories.description:
threat
    leads to danger- or fear-control.

theories.title: Fatigue
theories.description: The effects of tiredness.

theories.title: Frustration-Aggression Theory
theories.description:
when
stopped from reaching goal, people turn to aggression.

theories.title: Non-Verbal Behavior
theories.description:
we communicate
    hugely without words.

theories.title: Operant Conditioning
theories.description:
behavior
    + reward = more behavior (and vice versa).

theories.title: Rationalization Trap
theories.description:
dissonance
reduction leads to silly or immoral actions.

theories.title: Reactance Theory
theories.description:
prevention of action
    leads to action (to prove control).

theories.title: Realistic Conflict Theory
theories.description:
limited
resources leads to conflict.

theories.title:
Stockholm 
Syndrome
theories.description: becoming attached to captors.

theories.title: Symbolic Interaction Theory
theories.description:
we interact
with meaning of symbols.

theories.title: Epistemological Weighting Hypothesis
theories.description:
conformance
    depends on how closely our norms match group norms.

theories.title:
Conversion 
Theory
theories.description: Minorities can convert majority people.

theories.title: Group Locomotion Hypothesis
theories.description: members are motivated to achieve group goals.

theories.title: Groupthink
theories.description:
maintenance of group cohesion
    becomes all-important.

theories.title: Normative Social Influence
theories.description:
basic
    group need forces us to conform.

theories.title: Politeness Theory
theories.description:
we are nice where respect
    is needed (and vice versa).

theories.title: Roles
theories.description: we conform with shared expectations of behavior.

theories.title: Social Impact Theory
theories.description:
conformance
    increases with importance, immediacy and number of others.

theories.title: Social Norms
theories.description:
groups have rules that must be
    followed.

theories.title: Pluralistic Ignorance
theories.description:
sometimes most
people disagree with a group norm, but nobody speaks out.
